message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is showing signs of engorgement and lactation mastitis, which can be treated with cold compresses and analgesia. Oral contraceptives are not indicated in this case. Mammography is not necessary at this time, and incision and drainage are not appropriate management for engorgement and mastitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest engorgement of the breasts due to breastfeeding. Cold compresses and analgesia are the most appropriate first steps in management. Oral contraceptives are not indicated in this case. Mammography and incision and drainage are also not necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has mastitis, which is common in breastfeeding women. Cold compresses and analgesia are the most appropriate next step in management. Incision and drainage and mammography are not indicated for mastitis. Oral contraceptives may worsen the symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of engorged breasts and mastitis, which are common postpartum. The most appropriate next step in management is cold compresses and analgesia to relieve pain and inflammation. Oral contraceptives and mammography are not necessary at this point, and incision and drainage is not indicated unless there is an abscess present.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest she has engorgement of both breasts, likely due to breastfeeding. Cold compresses and analgesia are recommended as first-line management. Oral contraceptives and mammography are not indicated at this time. Incision and drainage are not appropriate for engorgement.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and recent delivery suggest engorgement of the breasts due to breastfeeding. Cold compresses and analgesia are the most appropriate next step in management. Incision and drainage is not appropriate for engorgement, and mammography is not needed at this time. Oral contraceptives may be an option to prevent engorgement in future pregnancies, but are not appropriate for acute management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient is experiencing postpartum engorgement, which can lead to mastitis. Cold compresses and analgesia are recommended as initial management, along with continuing to breastfeed frequently. Oral contraceptives and mammography would not be appropriate at this time. Incision and drainage are not necessary unless an abscess develops.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, especially the recent delivery and breastfeeding, suggest mastitis. The most appropriate next step in management is cold compresses and analgesia. Antibiotics may also be necessary if there are signs of infection, but they are not listed as an option. Oral contraceptives and mammography are not appropriate for this acute condition. Incision and drainage are only necessary in rare cases of abscess formation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest lactational mastitis, which is an inflammation of the breast tissue due to obstruction of milk flow. Treatment typically involves cold compresses and analgesia, as well as encouraging the patient to continue breastfeeding to prevent further engorgement. Oral contraceptives or mammography are not indicated in this case. Incision and drainage may be necessary if an abscess forms, but it is not the first-line treatment for lactational mastitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms of mastitis, which is an infection of the breast tissue that can occur during breastfeeding. The most appropriate next step in management is cold compresses and analgesia to reduce pain and inflammation. Oral contraceptives and mammography are not indicated in this case. Incision and drainage may be necessary in abscess formation, but this is not mentioned in the scenario.
